data.title: Support SEMO Marching Band while enjoying great music
data.meta_description: Organizers say all proceeds from the jazz orchestra concert go to support the SEMO Marching Band.
data.text:
CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo. (KFVS) - On Friday, August 9, the Southeast Missouri Regional Jazz Orchestra will put on the final show in their summer 2024 concert series.

The show begins at 7:30 p.m. at the Bedell Performance Hall on Southeast Missouri State University’s River Campus in Cape Girardeau.

Tickets start at $15 and can be purchased online or at the door.

Organizers say all proceeds go to support the SEMO Marching Band.

The Regional Jazz Orchestra is a group made up of music lovers from around the area. Teachers, students, and musicians come together each summer to perform.

Some of the group’s current members are SEMO Marching Band students as well, a group that’s received its second invitation in as many years to participate in the Bands of America Super Regional.

The opportunity will take them north to The Dome at America’s Center in St. Louis, as well as to Rock Bridge High School in Columbia, Missouri for an exhibition performance.

They’ll also perform at the Farmington High School, much closer to home.

According to the University, the current band is the largest in the institution’s history, meaning travel costs are larger as well.

“There’s 185 members of the marching band this year,” said Bailey Jennings, trumpet player and SEMO senior. “It really means a lot, because a lot of these kids are getting to go to where they’re from and show their families what they’re doing while at school.”

Jennings will perform on Friday, along with fellow seniors Ben Beckwith on trumpet and Sam Schwarm on trombone.

It’s a show they’re looking forward to playing.

“The community loves to engage with the music around here, that’s one of my favorite things about the place,” Beckwith said. “They love to see the different types of music that we bring, and the different influences, it’s really awesome.”

The concert follows many hours of rehearsals.

“I think you’re gonna hear really great music by some really great professionals, and it’s also going to a really great cause.” Schwarm said. “So a lot of really great [things] in the night.”

Opportunities with SEMO Marching Band are coming to a close for these three seniors, but their eyes are looking ahead to futures full of music.

For Schwarm, that means returning to his roots in St. Louis to teach high school band. Beckwith hopes to pursue a master’s degree in orchestral conducting. Meanwhile, Jennings’ goal is to start them young, teaching music to elementary school students.

All three will put their skills on display in the Regional Jazz Orchestra concert on August 9.
